option.name: title_text
option.value: Northeastern's Paid Leave Program for Non-Benefits-Eligible Employees

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: The Paid Leave Program is designed to support you and your family when you need help the most. Over the next few minutes, I’ll describe how this program works—and what it means to you. Let’s get started.

While prompted by the Massachusetts Paid Family and Medical Leave law, our Paid Leave Program is part of an ongoing effort to provide unified benefits for all employees—no matter where they live in the United States.

Our comprehensive leave program not only satisfies individual state regulations, it also distinguishes Northeastern as an employer of choice.

Plus, it simplifies your leave process and provides financial security if you need to take time off to care for yourself or your family.

Under the Paid Leave Program, non-benefits-eligible employees qualify for up to 20 weeks of Medical Leave with 80% pay if you experience a qualifying serious health condition. It’s important to note that this benefit begins after an unpaid 7-day waiting period. However, you can supplement the unpaid waiting period with up to 40 hours of family sick time.

Under the Paid Leave Program, you’ll also enjoy an extended Family Leave benefit providing 80% of your pay for up to 12 weeks to bond with your child after a birth, adoption, or foster care placement. Like Medical Leave, Family Leave also begins after an unpaid 7-day waiting period. However, you can supplement the unpaid waiting period with up to 40 hours of family sick time.

If you’re a birth mother, the seven-day waiting period is waived and your bonding time begins after your Medical Leave ends. Medical Leave timeframes will be determined by your medical team.

If you need to care for a family member with a qualifying serious health condition, you’re also eligible to use the new Family Leave benefit.

You may also use the benefit to care for a family member in the Armed Forces who is on active duty, has been notified of an impending call to active duty, or has a serious health condition resulting from deployment.

Need to use paid leave?

Visit the HR Service Center and search for the “Paid Leave Program.” Then, follow the prompts to provide the necessary information so that Human Resources can process your leave request.

If you have any questions, visit the HR Service Center. It has everything you need to learn about this new Paid Leave Program and all the benefits we offer to support you and your loved ones. Thank you!
